00005 import re
00006 import os

00009 def XmlToString(content, encoding='utf-8', pretty=False):
00010   """ Writes the XML content to disk, touching the file only if it has changed.
00011 
00012   Visual Studio files have a lot of pre-defined structures.  This function makes
00013   it easy to represent these structures as Python data structures, instead of
00014   having to create a lot of function calls.
00015 
00016   Each XML element of the content is represented as a list composed of:
00017   1. The name of the element, a string,
00018   2. The attributes of the element, a dictionary (optional), and
00019   3+. The content of the element, if any.  Strings are simple text nodes and
00020       lists are child elements.
00021 
00022   Example 1:
00023       <test/>
00024   becomes
00025       ['test']
00026 
00027   Example 2:
00028       <myelement a='value1' b='value2'>
00029          <childtype>This is</childtype>
00030          <childtype>it!</childtype>
00031       </myelement>
00032 
00033   becomes
00034       ['myelement', {'a':'value1', 'b':'value2'},
00035          ['childtype', 'This is'],
00036          ['childtype', 'it!'],
00037       ]
00038 
00039   Args:
00040     content:  The structured content to be converted.
00041     encoding: The encoding to report on the first XML line.
00042     pretty: True if we want pretty printing with indents and new lines.
00043 
00044   Returns:
00045     The XML content as a string.
00046   """
00047   # We create a huge list of all the elements of the file.
00048   xml_parts = ['<?xml version="1.0" encoding="%s"?>' % encoding]
00049   if pretty:
00050     xml_parts.append('\n')
00051   _ConstructContentList(xml_parts, content, pretty)
00052 
00053   # Convert it to a string
00054   return ''.join(xml_parts)
00055 
00056 
00057 def _ConstructContentList(xml_parts, specification, pretty, level=0):
00058   """ Appends the XML parts corresponding to the specification.
00059 
00060   Args:
00061     xml_parts: A list of XML parts to be appended to.
00062     specification:  The specification of the element.  See EasyXml docs.
00063     pretty: True if we want pretty printing with indents and new lines.
00064     level: Indentation level.
00065   """
00066   # The first item in a specification is the name of the element.
00067   if pretty:
00068     indentation = '  ' * level
00069     new_line = '\n'
00070   else:
00071     indentation = ''
00072     new_line = ''
00073   name = specification[0]
00074   if not isinstance(name, str):
00075     raise Exception('The first item of an EasyXml specification should be '
00076                     'a string.  Specification was ' + str(specification))
00077   xml_parts.append(indentation + '<' + name)
00078 
00079   # Optionally in second position is a dictionary of the attributes.
00080   rest = specification[1:]
00081   if rest and isinstance(rest[0], dict):
00082     for at, val in sorted(rest[0].iteritems()):
00083       xml_parts.append(' %s="%s"' % (at, _XmlEscape(val, attr=True)))
00084     rest = rest[1:]
00085   if rest:
00086     xml_parts.append('>')
00087     all_strings = reduce(lambda x, y: x and isinstance(y, str), rest, True)
00088     multi_line = not all_strings
00089     if multi_line and new_line:
00090       xml_parts.append(new_line)
00091     for child_spec in rest:
00092       # If it's a string, append a text node.
00093       # Otherwise recurse over that child definition
00094       if isinstance(child_spec, str):
00095        xml_parts.append(_XmlEscape(child_spec))
00096       else:
00097         _ConstructContentList(xml_parts, child_spec, pretty, level + 1)
00098     if multi_line and indentation:
00099       xml_parts.append(indentation)
00100     xml_parts.append('</%s>%s' % (name, new_line))
00101   else:
00102     xml_parts.append('/>%s' % new_line)
00103 
00104 
00105 def WriteXmlIfChanged(content, path, encoding='utf-8', pretty=False,
00106                       win32=False):
00107   """ Writes the XML content to disk, touching the file only if it has changed.
00108 
00109   Args:
00110     content:  The structured content to be written.
00111     path: Location of the file.
00112     encoding: The encoding to report on the first line of the XML file.
00113     pretty: True if we want pretty printing with indents and new lines.
00114   """
00115   xml_string = XmlToString(content, encoding, pretty)
00116   if win32 and os.linesep != '\r\n':
00117     xml_string = xml_string.replace('\n', '\r\n')
00118     
00119   try:
00120     xml_string = xml_string.encode(encoding)
00121   except Exception:
00122     xml_string = unicode(xml_string, 'latin-1').encode(encoding)
00123 
00124   # Get the old content
00125   try:
00126     f = open(path, 'r')
00127     existing = f.read()
00128     f.close()
00129   except:
00130     existing = None
00131 
00132   # It has changed, write it
00133   if existing != xml_string:
00134     f = open(path, 'w')
00135     f.write(xml_string)
00136     f.close()
00137 
00138 
00139 _xml_escape_map = {
00140     '"': '&quot;',
00141     "'": '&apos;',
00142     '<': '&lt;',
00143     '>': '&gt;',
00144     '&': '&amp;',
00145     '\n': '&#xA;',
00146     '\r': '&#xD;',
00147 }
00148 
00149 
00150 _xml_escape_re = re.compile(
00151     "(%s)" % "|".join(map(re.escape, _xml_escape_map.keys())))
00152 
00153 
00154 def _XmlEscape(value, attr=False):
00155   """ Escape a string for inclusion in XML."""
00156   def replace(match):
00157     m = match.string[match.start() : match.end()]
00158     # don't replace single quotes in attrs
00159     if attr and m == "'":
00160       return m
00161     return _xml_escape_map[m]
00162   return _xml_escape_re.sub(replace, value)
